captions.text: (camera click)
>> I was very surprised.

I had expected to get a picture
of a bear or a hog eventually.

I have a lot of deer, coyotes,
bobcat, turkey pictures,

but I didn't think I'd get
a mountain lion picture.
I was checking game camera

and I said, "Holy cow,
a mountain lion!"
I was quite surprised to see it.

>> Something unique
 is turning up

on game CAM photos
throughout Missouri.

Considered extinct in the state
since the 1920s,

sightings of mountain lions in
Missouri have been on the increase.

Both the popularity of inexpensive
game CAM technology

and western populations of
the big cats expanding their range

have led to over 40 confirmed
sightings in the state since 1994.

>> They're here,
they've never bothered us.

I've never seen one
with my own eyes.

I just had the camera in the
right place at the right time.

>> Mountain lions may be
coming back to Missouri,
but the question is why.
>> I think what's happening is

we're in the early stages
of re-colonization.

We're seeing more
and more cats visit the state.

Most of our cats we believe
are coming from the west.

We've had cats from Montana,
Colorado, and South Dakota.

The reason we know this is we were
able to get DNA from these cats.

So I think what we're seeing are
some of these western populations,
the young males are taking off.

I don't know
if we have a pipeline,

but there seems to be something
that they like about Missouri,
especially southern Missouri.

We have most of our confirmations
down there

and we've even 
had some animals that we think

we've taken multiple pictures of
over a course of several months.
That's kind of exciting.

Because you think of a transient
male as just moving on through,

but we're actually starting
to see some animals

we think that maybe
are establishing home ranges.

>> The Missouri Department
of Conservation

is not reintroducing
or stocking mountain lions,

and it has no intention
of doing so.

The agency does however have
a great interest in learning about

and monitoring
the natural re-colonization
that appears to be taking place.

>> We know from the picture
that that cat was standing
just about right here.

Now, right over here
is where your feeder was?

>> So generally what happens
is somebody will report

a mountain lion sighting
especially in most recent years

where game cameras
have gotten cheaper,
there are so many of them out

that we were presented
with a picture.

The challenge becomes
to document that that picture

was actually taken
in Missouri somewhere.

It's often not a question of what's
on the picture but where it was taken.

>> The second picture within
a couple hundred yards

of where the cat was there were
five or six young college students

out in hay field and they never
knew the cat was there,
it never bothered anyone.

It had to know they were there; they were
talking, laughing, having a good time.

We've never had problems with them,
and we still we don't.

>> For us to move forward
and confirm it,

we have to have some physical
evidence whether it is a picture

a cast of a track,
hair, scat, something.

The conservation agent, the
person investigating the report

never makes the statement of,
yes, it is a mountain lion, or it's not.

That report is forwarded to
our mountain lion response team

and they will make the decision
on whether to confirm it

as an occurrence of
a mountain lion in Missouri.

>> We have a trail CAM picture
here that is a little grainy.

>> Yeah, you know,
there's no scale.
It's got the right body shape;

it looks like there
could be a tail there.

>> But they also provided us
with some tracks they found,
wasn't 50 yards from that picture.
>> Those are pretty good cat tracks.
He was lucky to find those in that mud.
>> Yeah, those are pretty clear.

In my mind
coupled with that picture

I'm saying it's a pretty
solid confirmation in my mind.

>> Yeah, I agree, I'd say
we could confirm this one.

>> To learn more the department
has established

a mountain lion response team
to investigate

and confirm
mountain lion sightings.
>> It lines up, doesn't it?

>> Unlike many western states,
the people of Missouri have not

experienced living with large
predators for nearly a century.
Some are understandably concerned.

Could these animals pose
a threat to life or property?
>> I don't think so.
We've never had a --

we've never had an individual
attacked by a mountain lion.
And it's a rare event anywhere.
Mountain Lions are nocturnal.

They're hardly ever seen even in places
where there are a lot of mountain lions.

So if you did chance
an encounter with one

it's a pretty rare event
right there.

Even more rare event that
that lion acted aggressively

toward you or challenged you it
would be a very unusual thing.

But what you would want to do is
be aggressive toward that animal.

In other words stand your ground,
throw your hands up in the air,

perhaps yell at it,
throw sticks at it.

Do something to give that animal
a negative experience.

As they enter the state
they are considered

a fur bearer
with no open season.

They are protected, but if
a person has an issue with a lion

threatening or attacking them
or their livestock

they do have the right
to shoot that lion.
And we'd like to know about that

because we can learn a lot
from these animals as well.

>> So far sightings in Missouri
represent transient males;

there has been
no evidence of females
or of breeding within the state.

There is however evidence
of breeding mountain lions
in central Nebraska.

Though female lions do not disburse
nearly as far as male cats,
they are getting closer.

The last chapter of the story
of mountain lions in Missouri
has yet to be written.
